instructions.title: a x b
instructions.body:
Use C & D scales.
Either end 1 is used as index on the slide. Place left 1 over 2 on D, and read 4 below 2 on C, also 6 below 3 on C, etc. All numbers along the scale D are 2 X the number on C above them, with this setting.

instructions.title: a / b
instructions.body:
Use C & D scales.
Place 2 on the slide C over 4 on the D scale, read 2 on D scale, at the index of C. If you so desire, multiples of a proper fraction can be read directly.
Thus:
        C- 1  2 3 5
        D- 2 4 6 10

instructions.title: 1 / a
instructions.body:
Use the C & CI or D & DI scales.
Place the cursor at *a* on the C or D scale. Read from CI or DI scale, accordingly.

instructions.title: e^a
instructions.body:
Use the C scale and LL scales.

For example: e^5.3
Use the LL3 scale.
Place the cursor at 5.3 on the C scale, read 200 on the LL3 scale

Scale Ranges:
LL3: [1, 10],         LL2: [0.1, 1],        LL1: [0.01, 0.1],         LL0: [0.001, 0.01]
LL03: [-10, -1],   LL02: [-1, -0.1],   LL01: [-0.1, -0.01],   LL00: [-0.01, -0.001]

instructions.title: a ^ b
instructions.body:
Use the C & L scales.
a ^ b = 10 ^ (log(a) x b). Place the cursor at *a* on the C scale. Read at the L scale. Multiply that value by *b*. Place the cursor on the fractional portion of the product on the L scale. Read the result on the C scale.

For example: 23.2^1.8
Place the cursor at 2.32 on the C scale. Read 0.365 on the L scale. Note that since the L scale only provides the mantissa of the logarithm, the logarithm is actually 1.365. Move the cursor to 1.365 on the C scale, and move the index of the D scale to the cursor. Place the cursor at 1.8 on the D scale and read 2.457 on the C scale. Move the cursor to 0.457 on the L scale, and read 287 on the C scale.

instructions.title: log(a)
instructions.body:
Use the C & L scales.
Move the cursor to *a* on the C scale, read the **mantissa** of the *log(a)* on the L scale.

For example: log(82.4)
Place the cursor at 8.24 on the C scale. Read 0.92 on the L scale. Because 82.4 needs to be shifted one decimal place to become between 1 and 10, add 1 to the mantissa to get 1.92.

Note that for larger values of *a*, you will need to track of the characteristic of the logarithm, or the whole part of it.
Note that for values of *a* less than 1, you must calculate the negative of the log of the reciporcal of *a*. (-log(1/a))

instructions.title: ln(a)
instructions.body:
Calculate the common log (or simply log) of *a* on the L scale, then multiply the result by 2.303.

For example: ln(8.6)
Place the cursor at 8.6 on the C scale and read 0.934 on the L scale. Move the cursor to 9.34 on the C scale, and move the index of D to the cursor. At 2.303 on the D scale, read 2.15 on the C scale.
Note that for larger values of *a*, you will need to keep track of the characteristic of the logarithm, or the whole part of it.
